title: Daniel Marcotte on SproutCore 2.0 (now Ember.js)
author: Michael Norman
abstract: Daniel Marcotte is one of the top developers on our latest product offering, Customer Intelligence (CI). He spent quite a bit of time evaluating SproutCore 2.0 for the complex user interface requirements of CI, helping to work out some of the kinks in the product as it moved toward beta . Daniel has recently moved to San Francisco to work on a new project ‚Äî still for Bazaarvoice, of course! Before he left, I had a chance to sit down with him to chat about his experience working with the framework. MDN: Welcome, Daniel! Thanks for letting me take some time out of your hectic schedule to get you on record, so to speak. DM: Ah, my pleasure, Michael. Thank you for doing all the hard work. MDN: No, no, not at all. You did all the hard work already ‚Äî I‚Äôm just gonna put my name on it! DM: I‚Äôm a team player; you go right ahead! MDN: Awesome! So let‚Äôs get right down to it. You switch seamlessly between front-end and back-end development, and you‚Äôre very passionate about the user experience. A lot of developers in the industry want to work on back-end systems and don‚Äôt seem to get as excited about building great UIs. So, what do you think contributes to your passion? I‚Äôm really interested to hear what drives you because it also tends to drive the Web UI frameworks people choose. DM: Yeah, that‚Äôs fair. I‚Äôve actually given this a little bit of thought because my new manager asked me something about this recently. Something like, ‚ÄòWow, you know, you‚Äôre really a UI guy. That‚Äôs great; how did you get into that?‚Äô And I had kind of a funny moment, thinking it might be fruitful to start thinking of myself as a UI guy because then it‚Äôll focus me on taking time to even go the extra level. Maybe read some stuff about user experience and even more wacky technologies. Because, I hadn‚Äôt traditionally done that. So how did I even end up in this position where someone would think, ‚Äòof course you‚Äôre a UI guy‚Äô? I think it‚Äôs because I don‚Äôt wanna do a shitty job. So if you‚Äôve been tasked with building a UI feature, it needs to work. And it needs to be attractive. It needs to be usable. You need to put yourself in the user‚Äôs shoes. MDN: It‚Äôs amazing, but most people don‚Äôt think that way. It seems like you actually know a little bit more. Have you actually done any reading and learning about any of this? DM: I have, yeah‚Ä¶some. But nothing extensive. It‚Äôs a bit intuitive which I think gets people relatively far. And I think it has a lot to do with just being honest with yourself, of trying to put yourself in someone‚Äôs shoes maybe. I have a bit of a teaching background. It‚Äôs one of my great pleasures. (Let‚Äôs ramble a little bit.) And one of my favorite things was being able to find a way to explain something to someone who it was completely new and novel to. To never forget what that was like to learn it for the first time. ‚ÄòCause you can get lost and be an expert and think, ‚Äòoh, it‚Äôs obvious, it‚Äôs fine.‚Äô And I think that bleeds into UI sometimes. ‚ÄòOh, I know how to use this.‚Äô And that‚Äôs not the bar we‚Äôre trying to meet here. MDN: You were instrumental in choosing SproutCore 2.0 for CI. What other Web UI frameworks did you and the team look at before deciding on Sproutcore? DM: I looked at what Dojo was offering because it has the same full app/infrastructure stuff. It was a touch inscrutable, but really appealing. But it kind of seemed to go down the Ext-JS packaged-widget route. And I knew that Alex Zelenak, our UX designer, would come in and do a lot of custom stuff. And the other big driver, though I‚Äôm perceived as choosing this, I was really just the person who made it possible. It was really Alex Sexton that said, ‚Äòthis is the one; this is it for these reasons.‚Äô So that kind of focused it. And it sort of became the one, and it needed to lose for some reason as opposed to beat something else. MDN: Did Alex talk about Handlebars at all, because I know that he‚Äôs using it in other places. DM: Oh, that‚Äôs interconnected. You use Handlebars templating inside SproutCore. MDN: I‚Äôm just showing my ignorance! DM: It‚Äôs like a specialized version of Handlebars that‚Äôs bindings-aware. So as your values change, your templates re-render. MDN: You talked about this a little bit, but does SproutCore have widgets too? DM: No. They‚Äôd like to get there, but it‚Äôd be like a UI layer. This is more like the structure/spine of the app. MDN: So other than Alex‚Äôs stamp of approval, what are the other reasons you might use it in the future? DM: I like the way it makes me think. I like the flavor of thinking it lends itself to. This disconnect with the bindings‚Ä¶. (Let me see if I can package this a little bit.) Trying to wrangle web UI using HTML, CSS, JavaScript without making the classic disaster, the classic mess, has been a mission of mine for a while. What‚Äôs the answer? What‚Äôs the secret? How do we make this maintainable and obvious to the next developer? Extensible, that sort of stuff. And one of the big realizations I had a while ago was, with Don‚Äôt Repeat Yourself, the DOM, it‚Äôs the boss in so many things. I have a list of things I‚Äôm showing the user, and I don‚Äôt wanna duplicate in JavaScript having another list of things and try to synchronize those two. It‚Äôs much more a matter of saying something like‚Ä¶ DOM: you‚Äôre the boss. You‚Äôre displaying it. You have these nodes that represent my things. So if I need to reevaluate, I‚Äôm just gonna ask you, ‚ÄòHey dude, what‚Äôs my list look like?‚Äô OK, I‚Äôm gonna modify it inside you ‚Äôcause I wanna display it. ‚ÄòCause you‚Äôre the boss. And so in practice this works out really well. MDN: ‚ÄòCause that‚Äôs kind of how JQuery works because you have this separate set of code over here and it‚Äôs overlayed on top of the DOM. DM: Yeah exactly. But for some richer apps and much more complex apps, asking the DOM those questions gets more complicated ‚Äôcause stuff is kinda all over the place. And so you end up with these really bonkers selectors. And it‚Äôs slow to be constantly asking the DOM these questions to see what‚Äôs going on with it. So then you start to pull back and say, ‚ÄòOh, crap, I wish I had an object representation of this in my hand!‚Äô Is it worth writing this connective tissue? And so now, enter SproutCore, and the app is sort of pure JS and then you bind it to the UI and you don‚Äôt maintain that connection; SproutCore does. Which is cool. So the classic collections example that ties into the list example earlier, where before the DOM was the boss, now javaScript‚Äôs the boss. I have this list and I‚Äôm gonna monkey with it. Using observers and bindings, SproutCore‚Äôs gonna hold onto the fact that the list corresponds to something in the DOM, that‚Äôs rendered by a template. When the data changes, the template is called to re-render that piece. MDN: So SproutCore owns the DOM then. DM: Effectively, and it can do smart stuff like buffer your updates. So it‚Äôll just be like manually updating the DOM, but will be a lot faster. Then you kinda get into their flavor of MVC. SproutCore MVC gets quite appealing where you can really build an app that does its thing and then you can write unit tests against that. And when you bind the UI on it, that‚Äôs just another view. But independently, you have this app that you can validate does its thing and is independent of how it‚Äôs displayed. You do have to make sure you structure it carefully enough that you‚Äôre not getting into circular references in your bindings, but it‚Äôs super-appealing that your templates are HTML and you just bind them in with the app and there‚Äôs a lot of really great ideas. It‚Äôs technically very satisfying. MDN: And do you just bind it on top of a div element, because you‚Äôre going to have to put it in somewhere, right? So there‚Äôs some ID where you say, hey put this over here in this spot? DM: You have a script block that has a type ‚Äútext/html‚Äù or ‚Äútext/x-handlebars‚Äù. And one of the first things SproutCore does is it looks at the page and any script block of that type, if it has an ID on it, then it assumes you‚Äôre gonna reference this later and so it will just pull it out of the DOM and store it compiled. Otherwise, it‚Äôll replace it inline. You get to write very naturally, right inline, if you‚Äôre not reusing that component. It‚Äôs got a nice flow to it where it will just replace that piece with the markup it corresponds to. MDN: Did you run into any problems with SproutCore‚Äôs architecture as you were building out the system at all? DM: So, to even decide if we wanted to do this, I threw together a prototype that recreated what the pilot‚Äôs UI ‚Äî the interested parts ‚Äî did. And I was really able to see the value because we‚Äôre managing different views on the same data. And the user gets to toggle displayed data and interact with what they‚Äôre seeing. And so this idea of an app that will hold that state and where you can just swap out these views, it‚Äôs great because you can just say ‚Äúapp, here‚Äôs some data, do your thing‚Äù and now you‚Äôre not fetching from the server again and again if you just wanna re-slice something or have a different look at it, you have all that power easily in the client side. So that was all going really well, but then I‚Äôd run into mundane stuff. Like: you‚Äôve sent in a collection and you‚Äôre running over it and the designer wants to number each row. Perfectly reasonable request, but the context that you have in the collection rendering is just the collection item that you‚Äôre on. So do you artificially start adding indexes to your objects externally? Or do you say we should really have access to the index? And so that was kinda fun; I submitted a patch which exposed the current index when rendering a collection. Another example is that Tapestry [the server side web framework in this project] hosed us because you have almost no access to the head of the documents that it generates, which in general isn‚Äôt a problem, but in one of the early versions of SproutCore, it was only looking for stored templates in the head, which was an artificial restriction. MDN: But not really any big pains or roadblocks. Nothing you couldn‚Äôt work around or fix. DM: There was naturally a bit of instability in a few of the alpha versions I was using. And then there‚Äôs a tougher learning curve that goes with that: you can imagine being unable to distinguish between a flaw in understanding and a flaw in the library. But that‚Äôs come a long way. There are also things that it really super-facilitates incredibly, but as with a lot of these things, it can mean limiting you in other ways, like there being hoops to jump through to integrate with say a select control. And then we got into trouble where other developers started building out what I had there, and it wasn‚Äôt obvious that this code worked differently than they were used to. I hadn‚Äôt quite gotten it polished to the point of ‚Äúthis is how it‚Äôs done and you grow it from here and follow these patterns.‚Äù I hadn‚Äôt quite gotten there. The schedule comes in and you end up with this problem. So there was a bit of: ‚ÄúI wanna do this thing, and I can picture that vision in the ‚ÄòJQuery way.‚Äô Well now, what‚Äôs the ‚ÄòSproutCore way‚Äô of doing exactly that?‚Äù And you end up kind of cheating and creating artificial properties that you can bind to and kind of tricking it into doing things the ‚ÄòJQuery way‚Äô instead of doing what is really the ‚ÄòSproutCore way‚Äô. And that‚Äôs really challenging. MDN: Well, it‚Äôs the speed of sort of doing it versus doing it in a way that it‚Äôs gonna be good later. DM: Yeah. Do you want the speed now, or more of it later? And that‚Äôs a really hard choice to make. And I‚Äôve been ruminating on whether that‚Äôs a flaw on our part, or on the library‚Äôs part. How do we keep pushing that stuff forward and make it even better? I‚Äôm not sure. MDN: You made a pretty concerted effort to get SproutCore out of beta and into mainstream for release 2.0.
